key_findings: HESEIA is a dataset of 46,499 sentences created by 370 high-school teachers and 5,370 students from 189 Latin American schools, capturing intersectional biases across multiple demographic axes and school subjects relevant to their local contexts and lived experiences.

Unlike existing benchmarks that are crowdsourced, HESEIA was co-designed by educational communities through a professional development course where teachers used minimal pairs to create sentences expressing stereotypes relevant to their school subjects and communities.

The dataset demonstrates diversity in terms of demographic axes represented as well as the knowledge areas included, containing more stereotypes unrecognized by current large language models compared to previous datasets.

HESEIA is intended to support bias assessments grounded in the perspectives of communities affected by biases, addressing critiques that existing datasets may not adequately represent minority groups.
The co-design process with educators aimed to create a dataset that reflects local contexts and pedagogical expertise, capturing biases relevant to the lived experiences of the communities involved.

problem_addressed: Existing datasets for evaluating social biases in large language models may not adequately represent the perspectives and lived experiences of minority groups.
